elements.text: every year I come to the same sad realization. GUI's although used in almost all commercial applications - have horrendous solutions for developers. Why?
Not always. I did quite a lot of Salesforce development, and their user interfaces were earlier written in ‘Visualforce’ like this, similar to what early Java servers did too.

<apex:page standardController="Contact" >
    <apex:form >
        <apex:pageBlock title="Edit Contact">
            <apex:pageBlockSection columns="1">
                <apex:inputField value="{!Contact.FirstName}"/>
                <apex:inputField value="{!Contact.LastName}"/>
                <apex:inputField value="{!Contact.Email}"/>
                <apex:inputField value="{!Contact.Birthdate}"/>
            </apex:pageBlockSection>
            <apex:pageBlockButtons >
                <apex:commandButton action="{!save}" value="Save"/>
            </apex:pageBlockButtons>
        </apex:pageBlock>
    </apex:form>
</apex:page>

You could have Javascript, but it was uploaded to the server as a ‘resource’ with a name, totally separately.
Now skipping one UI framework that was used for some years (Aura Components), the new UI (Lightning Web Components) are written in standard formats.
In three files, HTML
I would expect that most organisations using it have some mixture of the three in use. And yes, these are random examples I copied from Trailhead.
